name: Kepler Space Telescope
description: Revolutionary space telescope that discovered over 2,600 confirmed exoplanets by detecting planetary transits.
objectives: Survey our region of the Milky Way to discover Earth-size and smaller planets
Determine the percentage of terrestrial and larger planets in or near the habitable zone
Determine the distribution of sizes and shapes of orbits of these planets
Estimate how many planets there are in multiple-star systems
achievements: Discovered 2,662 confirmed exoplanets
Found thousands more candidate planets
Revealed that planets are more common than stars
Discovered first Earth-size planet in habitable zone

name: TESS (Transiting Exoplanet Survey Satellite)
description: All-sky survey mission discovering transiting exoplanets around nearby bright stars.
objectives: Survey 200,000 of the brightest stars near the sun
Discover thousands of transiting exoplanets
Enable follow-up characterization of discovered planets
Focus on Earth and Super-Earth sized planets
achievements: Discovered over 400 confirmed exoplanets
Identified 6,000+ candidate exoplanets
Surveyed 75% of the sky in first two years
Enabled JWST follow-up observations

name: James Webb Space Telescope
description: Most powerful space telescope ever built, observing exoplanet atmospheres and early universe.
objectives: Study exoplanet atmospheres and compositions
Observe first galaxies formed after Big Bang
Study star and planet formation
Investigate dark matter and dark energy
achievements: First direct image of exoplanet HIP 65426 b
Detected water vapor in exoplanet atmospheres
Discovered most distant galaxies ever observed
Captured stunning images of nebulae and galaxies

name: Hubble Space Telescope
description: Iconic space telescope that revolutionized astronomy with unprecedented deep space observations.
objectives: Determine the age and expansion rate of the universe
Study formation and evolution of galaxies
Understand stellar evolution
Characterize exoplanet atmospheres
achievements: Helped determine universe is 13.8 billion years old
Discovered dark energy accelerating universe expansion
Photographed deep field images of distant galaxies
Detected exoplanet atmospheres and weather

name: Gaia
description: Creating the most accurate 3D map of our galaxy by measuring positions and motions of billions of stars.
objectives: Map 1 billion stars in the Milky Way
Measure star positions with unprecedented accuracy
Determine star velocities and properties
Discover asteroids, exoplanets, and distant quasars
achievements: Mapped over 1.8 billion stars
Created most detailed 3D map of Milky Way
Discovered thousands of asteroids
Measured parallax for billions of stars

name: CHEOPS
description: Characterizing known exoplanets by measuring their sizes with unprecedented precision.
objectives: Measure precise radii of known exoplanets
Characterize exoplanet densities and compositions
Study exoplanet atmospheres during transits
Search for additional planets in known systems
achievements: Characterized hundreds of exoplanet transits
Discovered ultra-hot Jupiter with titanium oxide
Found exoplanets with extreme temperatures
Enabled detailed follow-up of TESS discoveries

name: Spitzer Space Telescope
description: Infrared space telescope that revealed hidden universe and characterized exoplanet atmospheres.
objectives: Study the early universe in infrared
Characterize exoplanet atmospheres
Observe star and planet formation
Study galaxies and brown dwarfs
achievements: First detection of light from exoplanets
Discovered TRAPPIST-1 system had 7 planets
Created infrared maps of exoplanet weather
Observed most distant galaxies in infrared

name: PLATO
description: Future mission to discover and characterize Earth-like planets around Sun-like stars.
objectives: Find Earth-like planets in habitable zones
Characterize host stars with asteroseismology
Study planetary system architecture
Measure planet masses and ages

name: ARIEL
description: Future mission dedicated to studying exoplanet atmospheres and chemistry.
objectives: Survey 1,000 exoplanet atmospheres
Determine atmospheric compositions
Study exoplanet formation and evolution
Characterize diverse planetary types

name: International Space Station
description: Largest international space collaboration, serving as microgravity research laboratory.
objectives: Conduct microgravity research
Study long-term effects of spaceflight on humans
Develop technologies for deep space exploration
International cooperation in space
achievements: Continuous human presence since 2000
Over 3,000 research investigations
270+ individuals from 22 countries visited
Platform for Earth and space observations
